Twice weekly Litigation Transcript Generate. Weekly System (LTS) (1) Overview. The LTS program matches master file (MF) data (-V and -W freeze codes) with the Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) records of the Automated Transcript Insolvency System (AIS) database. Each week the data is systemically (LTS) extracted to a file that can be sorted by employee case assignment number or Insolvency group/unit number. (2) Sorting LTS Transcripts. The LTS transcripts are in one file and systemically sorted into the following types: (cid:129) After Petition (cid:129) All Other (optional for CIO) (cid:129) Case Closed on AIS (cid:129) Credit Balance with New Transaction (cid:129) New Assessments (cid:129) Other Credit Balance (3) Generating LTS Transcripts. To generate LTS transcripts the user must take the following actions: 1. Log into the AIS program, 2. Go to left side of screen, Misc Options, 3. Select Reports, 4. Scroll down to Litigation Transcripts, 5. Select Litigation Transcripts , 6. On right, set Parameters for Organization, 7. Click drop down by Audit Cycle, select cycle, 8. Select Cases on AIS,

) Pre-petition Credit and Pre-petition Liability. If a credit and liability are pre-petition, the caseworker must determine if the credit is a true module and payment. Based on local rules or standing orders, the credit balance may Balance” resolved by: a. manual refund to the debtor; b. manual refund mailed to the trustee; c. transfer of the credit to another period; or d. partial refund to the taxpayer and mailed refund to the trustee.

) Mining the Court’s Electronic Files. Insolvency is not to expend resources mining electronic filing systems used by the courts, such as PACER, to inde- pendently identify new filings of cases in chapters other than Chapter
The courts are obligated to notice the IRS when the Service has been listed as a creditor. (See Bankruptcy Rule
) If a pattern arises where the Service is not being noticed on cases where it is a creditor, FI must determine the cause and take necessary action. (See IRM
, Notices Not Received.) Depending upon local procedures, FI may find it beneficial to mine the court’s electronic files to identify new Chapter
filings. (

) Individual US Taxpayer. Individuals who are US citizens or residents are generally subject to tax on their worldwide income, regardless of source. who are residents of Puerto Rico are likewise subject to US income tax. However, except for wages paid to employees of the US federal government, bona fide residents of Puerto Rico (See Publication

, Tax Guide for Indi- viduals with Income from US Possessions) do not pay US tax on wage income derived from sources within Puerto Rico. Such individuals have a US federal income tax filing obligation only if their wages or other income from sources outside Puerto Rico exceeds the federal filing threshold (i.e., their deductions under IRC

relating to personal exemptions). Because US federal employees may not exclude their federal wages, they must file a US income tax return if their federal wages plus their income from sources outside Puerto Rico exceed the federal filing threshold. Individuals with self-employment income connected with a trade or business in Puerto Rico must file Form
-SS or Form
-PR and pay any resulting tax liability. (See IRM
, Puerto Rico - General Instructions.) (

) Business US Taxpayer. Employers located in Puerto Rico are treated the same as employers located in a state for purposes of the employment tax pro- visions of the IRC. The Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) imposes wage-based taxes on employers and employees in Puerto Rico to support Social Security and Medicare. And the Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) imposes a tax on wages paid to employees in Puerto Rico. Accordingly, employers and self-employed individuals must file employment tax returns (e.g., Forms
and
-SS or

-PR) with the IRS. Corporations organized outside the United States, including corporations organized in Rico, are generally treated as foreign corporations for US tax purposes. These corporations are taxed on their US source earnings and income that is effec- tively connected to a US trade or business, but income from Puerto Rico sources generally is not subject to US tax. ) Incorrectly Added Cases. If a case has been added to AIS even though debtor is not a US taxpayer, the case should be closed “OT” and input TORICO on the case classification screen. Caution: Once a case has been closed by Puerto Rico Insolvency with an “ OT,” the case is not to be reopened. Any questions about the “ OT” closure must be directed to the FI office in Puerto Rico. ) Unfiled Returns. Although IRPTR, Schedule I and/or the statement of financial affairs indicate a debtor should be a US taxpayer, the debtor may not have filed all required returns or may not have an account established on master file. As with any case where an estimated claim is filed, the responsibility for ensuring a master file account is established for the debtor(s) and valid dummy modules are created rests with the FI caseworker assigned to the account.
Note: Master file accounts are created by submitting Form 2363 to Centralized Case Processing.

) Payroll Deduction Installment Agreements. Payroll deduction installment agreements are voluntary. An employee under such an agreement can ask his employer to stop sending installment payments to the Service at the employ- ee’s discretion. However, Form

instructs the employer to “continue to make payments unless the IRS notifies you that the liability has been satisfied.” Consequently some employers mistake payroll deduction installment agreements for involuntary wage levies, and they refuse to halt payments to the Service at their employee’s request. When this situation occurs and the taxpayer is in bankruptcy, the easiest solution is to send the employer a Form
D,Release of Levy . This levy release may constitute a third party contact.
Automated Processes
) Overview of PIT Report. The CIO Technical Support units work Potential Invalid TIN (PIT) reports for all chapters of bankruptcy (except Chapters
TIN

). The PIT report, generated through IIP Process C, identifies AIS TINs may be incorrect by verifying AIS TIN data against IDRS master file tion. TINs on the PIT report do not pass master file validation and are suspected of being incorrect. These TINs are selected for manual review to decide the validity of the suspect TIN. (
) Valid TIN. A TIN is considered validated if: a. the name controls of AIS and CFOL (Corporate Files On-Line) match CC INOLES; or b. the AIS SSN matches the secondary spouse SSN from CFOL. (

) Forcing a Valid TIN. If the reviewer determines the suspect TIN is correct, acceptance of the TIN can be forced to the IIP system by updating the IIP file with a F (Force) in the IIP/IDRS process C/D field. Doing so enables add the secondary spouse SSN to the AIS TIN file or add an EIN to the TIN file. (

) Cumulative Listing. Any TIN listed on the PIT report will prevent the TC freeze code from posting to IDRS. IIP and all other initial case processing (including ALS research and CAG) is suspended until the TIN issue is resolved. The PIT report is a cumulative report (a potentially invalid TIN appears on each iteration of the report until it is resolved) and should be worked daily, but must be worked within two business days of generation. IDRS and court record research (through PACER, RACER, CM/ECF, or website www.uscourts.gov/allinks.html ) may be required to resolve the dis- crepancies identified by the report. (

) PIT Resolutions. To work PIT report issues, the reviewer may be required correct AIS information, Force the TIN through the IIP process, or X the TIN from IIP processing. Exempting a TIN from IIP Process C and D not necessarily resolve the problem TIN, but allows the reviewer to IIP processing. Ultimately, some PIT report problem TINs will be assigned bankruptcy caseworkers for final resolution. (

) Fatal Errors in Process K. Fatal errors prevent a process from completing tasks. Process K may experience a fatal error identified by “nd_interval.” particular fatal error can only be corrected by the ADS programmer. When nd_interval error is displayed:
the caseworker must email the CIO systems analyst (SA);

the programmer will provide the SA with the docket number and TIN caused the fatal error;
the SA must input a P on the TIN in ADS and instruct the technical support unit to run process K again for the affected territory;
the SA must email the docket number and TIN to the lead and manager the assigned discharge unit so the lead can work the discharge and
when finished working the discharge, the lead must change the P on to an M. (

) Automated Court Notices. The Electronic Noticing System (ENS) bankruptcy case information received through the Bankruptcy Noticing (BNC). ) Tolerance Amounts. The tolerance amount for this report will be annually by the Insolvency Territory Managers based on resources. (

) Field Actions. Field specialists must review each report and take actions based on local procedures for post-petition accruals, annotating the AIS history with the results of their review for each report received. (

) Generalized Unpostable Framework. The Campuses provide Insolvency groups listings of IDRS unpostable transaction codes, returns, and relating to bankruptcy cases. The Insolvency function, FI or CIO, that the transaction(s) that went unpostable is responsible for resolution of the resulting unpostable condition(s). (
) Examination List. Centralized Insolvency may receive action lists of cases which Examination has issued a statutory notice of deficiency and for assessment is prohibited by IRC §
CIO caseworkers will research status of each Exam case and reply by the deadline set by Exam. (See
), Exam’s “Hold” File.) (
) Weekly Nullified Distribution Lists. Unpostable transactions such as of TC
s are voided, and the originating unit is notified by the weekly Nullified Distribution Lists. (See IRM
, Nullified Distribution Lists.) (

) Local Controls/Monitoring. Campuses usually provide unpostable listings a weekly basis. Management should establish adequate controls to ensure postables are reviewed and follow-up actions are performed in a timely manner. (

Definitions of “Aged” Cases. A Chapter 7 No Asset case is considered if it has been open nine months or more since the petition date. Chapter 7 Asset cases become aged two years after the petition date. Chapter 11 cases are defined as aged if still open six years after the petition date. A Chapter 13 case is designated aged when it remains open on AIS more than six years after the petition date. Valid legal or processing reasons may keep cases longer than the timeframes given above.
Aged Case Report Actions. The report is worked annually for all chapters. The following tables reflect the process steps to run and work these reports.

) Eureka Reports. Eureka reports may be used in lieu of the AIS reports. (
) Pacer Match CIO may use the Pacer Match in conjunction with the Aged Reports. (
) Retention. Aged case reports must be retained for two years. (
) IAT Tools. CIO employees must use the Integrated Automation (IAT) tools shown in Exhibit

whenever possible. The use of some of the tools is mandatory when applicable for use. The IAT tools simplify ing by assisting the user with IDRS research and input. The tools reduce the chance of errors and improve productivity. They are desktop productivity enhancing tools. The IAT Website should be checked periodically for new that may assist in processing cases. Descriptions of each tool as well as job aids for each tool can be found on the IAT website. (
) Mandated Tools. If a mandated tool is not used because it was determined not to be appropriate due to a specific situation, those circumstances should be documented in the case file. (

) IAT Tools not Available. If an IAT tool is not available, or an employee has problem with the IAT Task Manager, the case should be processed through IDRS following established procedures. Make a note in the case file if an tool is not used. (
